The current Safety Data Sheet (SDS) for anhydrous ammonia is included in Appendix E. 

IX.	Emergency Communications
The telephone numbers of agencies and plant personnel that may be contacted in case of an emergency are available onsite.
 

X.	Planned Changes to Improve Safety
Chemical safety is an important part of Home Run Inn operations. Home Run Inn recently conducted a process hazard analysis (PHA) of their ammonia refrigeration system and will be dutifully implementing the recommendations from that PHA. Continuous improvement in safety is an important goal for Home Run Inn.  

XI.	Management Program
Home Run Inn has developed a management system to oversee the implementation of the risk management program elements.  This system has assigned qualified person(s) (or position) to assist in the development, implementation, and integration of the risk management program elements.  If any portion of the program is delegated to others, the names or positions of those individuals will be documented and the lines of authority defined through an organization chart or similar document.  Currently, Phillip DeYoung, Plant Engineer of Home Run Inn is responsible for implementation of the overall Risk Management Program.

at ensures compliance audits are conducted at a minimum of every three years to verify that Home Run Inn PSM/RMP practices and procedures are adequate and are being followed.  The most recent compliance audit was completed September 2, 2021.    
	Hot Work Permits  Home Run Inn has developed a best management practice for hot work.  
 

VII.	Five-Year Accident History
The Home Run Inn facility has not had an accidental anhydrous ammonia release, which resulted in deaths, injuries, or significant property damage onsite, or known offsite deaths, injuries, evacuations, sheltering in place, property damage, or environmental damage in the last five years. 

VIII.	Emergency Response Program
Home Run Inn has developed an emergency action plan to ensure that in the event of an emergency the facility personnel are aware of the appropriate actions to take and authorities to contact in order to mitigate the effects of a release.  

Home Run Inn has communicated and trained facility employees on proper evacuation procedures and has had interaction with the Lemont and Woodridge Fire Departments.  

Home Run Inn has coordinated their emergency action plan with the DuPage County Local Emergency Planning Committee (LEPC) and the Lemont and Woodridge Fire Departments.  This coordination effort includes providing each aforementioned agency with a copy of our Tier II report with a site diagram and hazardous material information.

Although Home Run Inn does not have an onsite hazardous materials response team, contractors currently utilized for operation and maintenance of the refrigeration system have received HAZWOPER training through classroom instruction, on-the-job training, and drills.  The current HAZWOPER training includes the first responder awareness level, the first responder operations level, and hazardous materials technician training.    

The facility has multiple windsocks present onsite for use in determining wind direction in the event of an ammonia release and evacu

maintain the system.
 
	Management of Change  Home Run Inn has developed a site-specific management of change procedure that ensures changes (except for replacement in kind) to the ammonia process, such as additions of new equipment or changes in operating, maintenance, or other procedures are documented. 
	Pre-Startup Review  Home Run Inn has developed a site-specific pre-startup safety review procedure that ensures a safety review is performed when modifications to the ammonia process are significant enough to require a change in PSI.
	Mechanical Integrity  Home Run Inn has updated a site-specific mechanical integrity procedure that ensures written preventative maintenance procedures are developed and maintained, preventative maintenance tests and inspections are properly documented, and employees maintaining the process receive adequate training.  
	Contractor Qualifications  Home Run Inn has developed a site-specific contractor qualification procedure that ensures all contract employers safety performance and programs are evaluated, a contract employee injury and illness log is maintained, information of potential hazards are communicated between Home Run Inn and the contract employer, and required training and information is communicated, such as the provisions of the emergency action plan and control over entrance into process areas.
	Incident Investigation  Home Run Inn has developed a site-specific incident investigation procedure that ensures each incident that either results in a release or could have resulted in a release of anhydrous ammonia is investigated, within 48 hours, by a team of at least one person knowledgeable in the process.  This procedure will also make provisions to ensure a report is prepared at the conclusion of the investigation and findings are promptly addressed. No ammonia releases have been reported within the past five (5) years.
	Compliance Audit  Home Run Inn has developed a site-specific compliance audit program th

revention program and a brief description are listed below.
	Employee Participation  Home Run Inn has developed a site-specific employee participation plan that ensures employees and their representatives are consulted when conducting and developing process hazard analyses and other information required to be developed under the PSM/RMP regulation.  In addition, the employee participation program will ensure employees and their representatives have access to process hazard analyses and all other information required to be developed under PSM/RMP.  
	Process Safety Information  Home Run Inn maintains a site-specific PSI program that ensures information pertaining to the hazards, technology, and equipment of the process are properly developed and maintained. 
	Process Hazard Analysis  Home Run Inn has developed a site-specific PHA program that ensures a PHA is conducted initially, at a minimum of every five (5) years, and whenever a change is significant enough to require a change in PSI.  In addition, this program ensures PHAs are conducted in accordance with OSHA and EPA regulations and ensures findings and recommendations of PHAs are properly documented. Home Run Inn completed a thorough PHA revalidation study for the ammonia refrigeration system on January 6, 2022.
	Operating Procedures  Home Run Inn has updated a site-specific procedure that ensures operating procedures provide clear instruction for different phases of process operations and ensures they are properly maintained.  Home Run Inn completed a thorough review and certification of operating procedures for the refrigeration system on November 3, 2022.
	Training  Home Run Inn has developed a site-specific training procedure that ensures employees operating the ammonia process have the knowledge to safely operate the process, are aware of the potential hazards of the process, and understand the causes of process problems. However, refrigeration contractors are currently relied upon to operate and

e the safety of all employees, contractors, and visitors in the event of an emergency and also guard against environmental consequences. 

III.	Facility Identification
The Home Run Inn facility is located at 1300 International Parkway in Woodridge, Illinois. The NAICS code for the facility is 311412  Frozen Specialty Food Manufacturing. 

The facility uses ammonia for refrigeration, and is regulated under 40 CFR Part 68, the EPA RMP Rule. 

The amount of ammonia currently present in the refrigeration system is approximately 18,400 pounds.  The refrigeration system is used to cool process areas, coolers, and freezers.

An aerial photo identifying the site location is included as Appendix A. 

IV.	Hazard Assessment  Worst Case Scenarios (WCS)
Appendix B consists of the RMP*Submit Printout and contains additional information on the worst-case scenario.  Appendix C consists of the offsite consequence analysis data and maps for the worst case release scenario. 

V.	Hazard Assessment  Alternative Release Scenarios (ARS)
Appendix B consists of the RMP*Submit Printout and contains additional information on the alternative release scenario.  Appendix D consists of the offsite consequence analysis data and maps for the alternative release scenario. 

 
VI.	General Accidental Release Prevention Program
A prevention program is in place to minimize the risk of hazardous chemical releases in accordance with the OSHA Process Safety Management (PSM) standard (29 CFR 1910.119) and the EPA Risk Management Program.   However, as discussed throughout this document Home Run Inn is continuously improving this program. 

This prevention program covers those processes that handle ammonia above the threshold quantity for both PSM and RMP rules. The most recent audit of the PSM program was conducted on September 2, 2021, and the next audit will occur before September 2, 2024, in compliance with the requirement to conduct PSM audits every three years.
